newsitem.title: NEPAL: Nepal plans to privatise telecom, publishing firms.
newsitem.headline: Nepal plans to privatise telecom, publishing firms.

text.p: Nepal plans to privatise a state-owned telecommunications company and a publishing house, Finance Minister Rabindra Nath Sharma said on Monday.

"The Telecommunications Corporation and Gorkhapatra Corporation under the Ministry of Information and Communications have been selected for study under the third phase of privatisation," Sharma told parliament in a statement.
Under the first two phases the Himalayan kingdom sold off 15 public enterprises under an economic reform programme launched in 1992.
The Nepal Telecommunication Corporation (NTC) has a monopoly of telecommunication services and meets 41 percent of the total demand of 340,000 connections with its 140,000 telephone lines.
The Gorkhapatra Corporation has six publications including two daily newspapers, the English language Rising Nepal and the Nepali language Gorkhapatra, the country's oldest newspaper.
The communists, who dominate the nation's four-month-old centre-left coalition government, had criticised the privatisation drive while in opposition, saying some corporations had been undervalued.

"The study (for the third phase) will take into account the financial and management status of the corporations, their business and market positions and prospects for growth," Tanka Khanal, privatisation chief at the Finance Ministry, told Reuters.
Sharma said the government will take care of employee interests while moving ahead with privatisation.
Last year, the government invited private firms to start radio paging, wireless in local loop (WLL) and mobile phone services to meet the country's increasing demand for telephone lines.
But the move was challenged in the Supreme Court which has yet to give its verdict. Without the court's ruling the government cannot implement its privatisation plan.
